{{about||the golf tournament|KCB Karen Masters}} {{Infobox person | name = Karen Masters | image = Karen_Masters,_astronomer,_December_2017.jpg | birth_date = 1979 | alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]] | organization = [[Haverford College]] | known_for = [[Astrophysics]] , formation and evolution, [[Galaxy Zoo]] }}
'''Karen Masters''' (born 1979) is an Associate Professor of [[Astrophysics]] interested in galaxy formation who works in [[Haverford College]], Pennsylvania. She is project scientist for the citizen science project [[Galaxy Zoo]], and uses the classifications to study the evolution of galaxies.
== Education == Masters was born in Birmingham and attended [[King Edward VI College, Nuneaton]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://blog.galaxyzoo.org/2009/11/02/shes-an-astronomer-karen-masters/|title=She's an Astronomer: Karen Masters|date=2009-11-02|work=Galaxy Zoo|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US}}</ref> She completed a BSc in Physics at the University of Oxford in 2000.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wadham.ox.ac.uk/people/alumni/m/karen-masters|title=Waham College Alumni: Karen Masters|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Oxford|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> She received a PhD in Astronomy from Cornell University in 2005, entitled "Galaxy flows in and around the Local Supercluster", under the supervision of [[Martha P. Haynes|Martha Haynes]] and [[Riccardo Giovanelli]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Masters|first=Karen Louise|date=2005|title=Galaxy flows in and around the Local Supercluster|bibcode=2005PhDT.........2M|journal=Ph.D. Thesis}}</ref>
== Research == In 2005 Masters moved to Harvard University to work as a postdoctoral researcher with [[John Huchra]] on a project to make the most complete map of the local Universe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/profiles/karen-masters-91585|title=Karen Masters|website=The Conversation|language=en|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> Masters "unveiled the most complete 3-D map of the local universe (out to a distance of 380 million light-years) ever created"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://insider.si.edu/2011/05/astronomers-unveil-the-most-complete-3-d-map-of-the-local-universe/|title=Astronomers unveil the most complete 3-D map of the local universe|date=2011-05-25|work=Smithsonian Insider|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US}}</ref> in 2011 at the 218th meeting of the [[American Astronomical Society]]. The map was created using data from the [[2MASS|Two-Micron All-Sky Survey]].
She moved to the [[Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth|Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation]] at the [[University of Portsmouth]] in October 2008.<ref name=":0" /> She was appointed the [[Gruber Foundation]] IAU Fellow in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gruber.yale.edu/cosmology/press/2008-gruber-cosmology-prize-press-release|title=2008 Gruber Cosmology Prize Press Release {{!}} The Gruber Foundation|website=gruber.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> In 2010 Masters was awarded a Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship, for a project entitled "Do bars kill spiral galaxies?".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://researchportal.port.ac.uk/portal/en/persons/karen-masters(3620b915-0a34-4e9c-b7f1-d82ea421a3c3).html|title=Karen Masters - Portsmouth Research Portal|website=researchportal.port.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> She was promoted to Senior Lecturer in 2014 and Associate Professor in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.icg.port.ac.uk/author/mastersk/|title=Karen Masters|website=www.icg.port.ac.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> She has been working on extragalactic astronomy, and in 2018 was appointed as Associate Professor at [[Haverford College]] in Pennsylvania.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haverford.edu/college-communications/news/haverford-welcomes-six-new-faculty-members|title=Haverford Welcomes Six New Faculty Members|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en}}</ref>
Masters is the Scientific Spokesperson and Director for Education and Public Engagement for the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sdss.org/contact/|title=Contact {{!}} SDSS|website=www.sdss.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref>
== Public engagement == Masters coordinates the research scientists for Galaxy Zoo, a crowd-sourced galaxy classification project.<ref name=":1" /> She has appeared on the [[BBC Sky at Night|BBC Sky At Night]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07g9z87|title=Secrets of the Whirlpool Galaxy, The Sky at Night - BBC Four|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref>
She coordinated the She's An Astronomer page for Galaxy Zoo, collating the stories of women from astronomy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.galaxyzoo.org/category/shes-an-astronomer-3/|title=She’s An Astronomer {{!}} Galaxy Zoo|website=blog.galaxyzoo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> In 2014 Masers won the Women of the Future Award for Science.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ras.org.uk/news-and-press/2527-dr-karen-masters-wins-women-of-the-future-award|title=Dr Karen Masters wins Women of the Future award|last=Massey|first=Robert|website=www.ras.org.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.sdss.org/2014/10/31/the-future-is-now-karen-masters-wins-uk-award/|title=The Future is Now: Karen Masters Wins UK Award {{!}} Science Blog from the SDSS|website=blog.sdss.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> That year she was listed as one of the BBC's top 100 women.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-29758792|title=Who are the 100 Women 2014?|date=2014-10-26|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Masters, Karen}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women physicists]] [[Category:Women astrophysicists]] [[Category:Citizen science]] [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Women astronomers]]

'''Kosmos 57''' was an unmanned [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] Spacecraft launched on 22 February 1965.{{Cite book|title=Spaceflight and Rocketry|last=Baker|first=David|publisher=Facts on File Inc.|year=1996|isbn=0-8160-1853-7|location=United States of America|pages=176}} The craft was essentially an unmanned version of [[Voskhod 2]]. Its primary mission was to test the Volga [[airlock]]. The test was successful, but the craft was lost shortly after. The Spaceflight is designated under the [[Kosmos (satellite)|Kosmos]] system, placed with many other Soviet scientific and military satellites. File:Vostok_spacecraft.jpg| Vostok File:Voskhod_1_and_2.png| Voskhod 1 and 2 File:Voskhod-2_airlock_and_spacesuit.jpg| Voskhod 2,
Airlock and spacesuit == Description == *Mass: 5682.0 kg [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1965-012A Cosmos 57, NSSDCA/COSPAR ID: 1965-012A], NASA notice == Mission == The unmanned craft was launched three weeks before Voskhod 2. The primary objective of Voskhod 2 was to conduct a [[Extravehicular activity|spacewalk]], which relied on the inflatable Volga airlock. Kosmos 57 was to test the performance of the airlock. The airlock opened and closed successfully and the craft was re-pressurized without flaw.{{Cite book|title=Escaping the Bonds of Earth|last=Evans|first=Ben|publisher=Praxis Publishing|year=2009|isbn=978-0-387-79093-0|location=Chichester, UK|pages=196}} == Orbital Parameters == {|class="wikitable" |+ |- !Parameter !Value |- | Periapsis || 165 km |- | Apoapsis || 427 km |- | Period || 91.1 minutes |- | Inclination || 64.8° |- | Eccentricity ||0.01961 |} == Destruction == The unmanned spacecraft was destroyed on its third [[orbit]] around [[Earth]]. Two [[ground control station]]s, one in Klyuchi and the other in Yelisovo, sent simultaneous commands instructing the craft to depressurize its airlock. The craft interpreted this as an order to begin descent and a [[propulsion]] error put the craft into a tumble. Approximately twenty-nine minutes later the craft's automatic self-destruct function activated. The craft was completely destroyed to prevent sensitive information from literally falling into enemy hands. Over 100 pieces of the spacecraft were tracked, falling into the ocean between 31 March and 6 April 1965.{{Cite book|title=The Rocket Men, Vostok and Voskhod, the First Soviet Manned Spaceflights|last=Hall|first=Rex|last2=Shayler|first2=David|publisher=Praxis Publishing|year=2001|isbn=1-85233-391-X|location=Chichester, UK|pages=243}} == See also == {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[[List of Kosmos satellites]] *[http://www.britannica.com/topic/Cosmos-satellite Overview at Encyclopaedia britannica] *[http://claudelafleur.qc.ca/Spacecrafts-1965.html Spacecraft launches in 1965, Overview] == References == [[Category:Earth observation satellites of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Voskhod program]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1965]] [[Category:1965 in the Soviet Union]]

<!---------------------- IMAGE & MAP --> | image = Lewis-and-clark-river.jpg | image_caption = Lewis and Clark River near its source at Saddle Mountain | image_size = 300 | map = | map_size = 300 | map_caption = | pushpin_map = USA Oregon | pushpin_map_size = 300 | pushpin_map_caption= Location of the mouth of the Lewis and Clark River in Oregon <!---------------------- LOCATION --> | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[United States]] | subdivision_type2 = State | subdivision_name2 = [[Oregon]] | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = | subdivision_type4 = County | subdivision_name4 = [[Clatsop County, Oregon|Clatsop]] | subdivision_type5 = | subdivision_name5 = <!---------------------- PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS --> | length = {{convert|20|mi|km|abbr=on}} | width_min = | width_avg = | width_max = | depth_min = | depth_avg = | depth_max = | discharge1_location= | discharge1_min = | discharge1_avg = | discharge1_max = <!---------------------- BASIN FEATURES --> | source1 = [[Northern Oregon Coast Range]] | source1_location = [[Saddle Mountain (Clatsop County, Oregon)|Saddle Mountain]], [[Clatsop County, Oregon|Clatsop County]], [[Oregon]] | source1_coordinates= {{coord|45|57|49|N|123|38|21|W|display=inline}}<ref name="gnis">{{GNIS|1123054|Lewis and Clark River}}</ref> | source1_elevation = {{convert|2100|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="source">Source elevation derived from [[USGS]] topo map (Note: the source coordinates provided by the USGS GNIS webpage are clearly wrong.</ref> | mouth = [[Youngs River]] | mouth_location = [[Youngs Bay]], [[Clatsop County, Oregon|Clatsop County]], [[Oregon]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|46|10|6|N|123|51|47|W|display=inline,title}}<ref name="gnis"/> | mouth_elevation = {{convert|3|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="gnis"/> | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|62|sqmi|abbr=on}}<ref name=WBD>{{cite web |title= Watershed Boundary Dataset |publisher= [[United States Department of Agriculture]], [[Natural Resources Conservation Service]] |url=http://www.ncgc.nrcs.usda.gov/products/datasets/watershed/ |accessdate= 4 September 2010}}</ref> | tributaries_left = | tributaries_right = | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }} The '''Lewis and Clark River''' is a tributary of [[Youngs River]], approximately {{convert|20|mi|km}} long, in northwest [[Oregon]] in the [[United States]]. It drains {{convert|62|sqmi|km2}} of the [[Northern Oregon Coast Range]] in the extreme northwest corner of the state, entering Youngs River just above its mouth on the [[Columbia River]] at [[Youngs Bay]]. Near the river's mouth is the site of former [[Fort Clatsop]] of the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]]. The river is named for [[Meriwether Lewis]] and [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]].
==History and parks== The river was called the Netul River by Lewis and Clark and the Native American [[Clatsop]] people who were living in the area at the time. It continued to be known as the Netul River until 1925, when it was renamed to honor Lewis and Clark.<ref>{{cite web | title = A Lasting Legacy: The Lewis and Clark Place Names of the Pacific Northwest - Part IV | last = Wesselius | first = Allen | publisher = Columbia Magazine | url = http://whs1.order-vault.net/wshs/wshs/columbia/articles/0401-a4.htm | accessdate = May 13, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The river flows through [[Lewis and Clark National and State Historical Parks]], which were collectively designated as a [[National Historical Park]] in 2004.
==Fish== The river is home to bottom-feeding [[sturgeon]], which is a popular sport fish in the area. It is also home to an extensive [[salmon]] repopulation program, just outside Astoria, Oregon proper, that is currently run by the [[Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife]]. The salmon fry, called "fingerlings" can be seen writhing and jumping within their net-lined pens along the river's eastern banks.{{Citation needed|reason=sources please, especially for the "popular" and "can be seen" sentences.|date=May 2009}} The river also supports runs of wild [[steelhead]] and [[cutthroat trout]].
==See also== *[[Skipanon River]] *[[List of rivers of Oregon]] *[[List of tributaries of the Columbia River]]

[[File:Flags-of-Vancouver-Canada-BC.jpg|thumb|right|The flags of [[Vancouver]], Canada, and [[British Columbia]]; the Canadian flag takes place of precedence in the centre]] [[File:Terry Fox Memorial 2008.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Flag of Canada|Canadian national flag]] flying next to a statue of [[Terry Fox]]]] This is a list of '''flags used in Canada'''. The [[Department of Canadian Heritage]] lays out protocol guidelines for the display of flags, including an order of precedence; these instructions are only conventional, however, and are generally intended to show respect for what are considered important symbols of the state or institutions.{{Cite web| url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/etiqtt/index-eng.cfm| last=Department of Canadian Heritage| authorlink=Department of Canadian Heritage| title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion > Flag Etiquette in Canada| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=18 September 2010}} The [[Queen's Personal Canadian Flag|Queen's personal standard]] is supreme in the order of precedence, followed by those for the monarch's representatives (depending on jurisdiction), the personal flags of other members of the [[Monarchy of Canada#Canadian Royal Family|Royal Family]],{{Cite web| url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/etiqtt/102-eng.cfm| last=Department of Canadian Heritage| authorlink=Department of Canadian Heritage| title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion > Personal Flags and Standards| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=18 September 2010}} and then the [[Flag of Canada|national flag]] and provincial flags. Many museums across Canada display historic flags in their exhibits. The [[Canadian Museum of History]], in [[Hull, Quebec]] has many culturally important flags in their collections. [[Settlers, Rails & Trails]] Inc., in [[Argyle, Manitoba]] holds the 2nd largest exhibit - known as the [[Canadian flag collection|Canadian Flag Collection]]. ==Royal== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;background-color:#fff;border: 1px #6082B6 solid;" style="width:100%;background-color:#fff;border: 1px #6082B6 solid;" |- ! style="width:15%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Flag !! style="width:10%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Date !! style="width:30%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Use !! style="width:45%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Description |- | [[File:Royal Standard of Canada.svg|100px|border]] || 1962–present || [[Royal standards of Canada#Sovereign's standard|Royal Standard of Canada]] || A banner of the [[Arms of Canada|Royal Arms of Canada]] defaced with a [[royal cypher]] of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] |- | [[File:Royal Standard of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.svg|100px|border]] || 1952–present || [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]]
Consort of [[Elizabeth II]]
(1952–present) | The Standard is based on the Duke's [[Greece|Greek]] and [[Denmark|Danish]] roots. The flag is divided into four quarters: The first quarter, representing Denmark, consists of three blue lions passant and nine red hearts on a yellow field. The second quarter, representing Greece, consists of a white cross on a blue field. The third quarter, representing the duke's surname, [[Mountbatten]], contains five black and white vertical stripes. The fourth quarter, alludes to his title as Duke of Edinburgh, and includes a black and red castle which is also part of the city of Edinburgh's arms. |- | [[File:Royal Standard of the Prince of Wales (in Canada).svg|100px|border]] || 2011–present || [[Royal standards of Canada#Other members of the Royal Family|Royal Standard of Prince Charles, the Prince of Wales]] || A banner of the [[Arms of Canada|Royal Arms of Canada]] defaced with the [[Prince of Wales's feathers]] and a 3-point label. |- | [[File:Royal Standard of Prince William (in Canada).svg|100px|border]] || 2011–present || [[Royal standards of Canada#Other members of the Royal Family|Royal Standard of Prince William, the Duke of Cambridge]] || A banner of the [[Arms of Canada|Royal Arms of Canada]] defaced with the [[royal cypher]] of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], and a 3-point label with one red scallop, representing the coat of arms of his mother, [[Diana, Princess of Wales]]. |- | [[File:Royal Standard of Princess Anne, Princess Royal (in Canada).svg|100px|border]] || 2013–present || [[Royal standards of Canada#Other members of the Royal Family|Royal Standard of Princess Anne, Princess other two, Saint-George's crosses. |- | [[File:Royal Standard of Prince Andrew, Duke of York (in Canada).svg|100px|border]] || 2014–present || [[Royal standards of Canada#Other members of the Royal Common in Prince Edward Island, New Brunswick, Quebec, and Nova Scotia. |- | [[File:Flag of Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean.svg|100px|border]] || 1938–present || Flag of [[Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean]] || A field party per fess, green and yellow, with a red-bordered grey ordinary cross; green represents the region's forests, yellow its agriculture, grey its industry and commerce, and red the vitality of the population |- | [[File:Flag of Labrador.svg|100px|border]] || 1974–present || [[Flag of Labrador]] || A field party per fess, white and azure, with a green horizontal band across the centre and a spruce twig in the upper hoist |- |[[File:Flag of Vancouver Island.svg|100px|border]] || 1988–present || [[Flag of Vancouver Island]] || A Blue Ensign defaced with the great seal of the Colony of Vancouver Island. Used informally today.[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/ca-bc-vi.html FOTW Flags of the World: Vancouver Island (British Colony, Canada)] This unofficial flag was designed in the 1980s to retroactively represent the colony (1849–1866). In 1865 the Crown gave colonies permission to place their badges on the fly of the Blue Ensign; thus vexillologists could argue that this flag is official.[http://www.fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Provinces/BC.html Flags of Canada: British Columbia] |- |[[File:Flag of Western Canada.png|100px|border]] || 1988–present || Flag of [[Western Canada]] || Originally used by the [[Western Independence Party]], it was designed in 1988 ahead of the party's first election. |- |[[File:Flag of the Republic of Madawaska.gif|100px|border]] |1938–present |Flag of [[Republic of Madawaska]] |The flag represents the Republic of Madawaska, with Edmundston (New Brunswick) as its unofficial capital. The region celebrates its distinct heritage, composed of the original Acadian population that founded the area, with a strong Lower-Canada immigration which absorbed this population, as well as the Franco-American population living on the other side of the St-John river where the boundaries were determined by the Webster-Ashburton treaty of 1842, splitting the community in Canada and the USA. |- The maple leaves at the bottom of the shield are red. |- | [[File:Royal Canadian Air Force Ensign (1941-1968).svg|100px|border]]|| 1941–1965|| [[Royal Canadian Air Force Ensign]] || A field of air force blue with the Union Flag in the canton and the Canadian roundel in the middle of the fly. |- |[[File:King's Colour of Royal Military College of Canada.jpg|100px]]|| −1965|| Based King's Colour, as used by the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] || King's Colour of the Royal Military College of Canada with the Union Flag. |- |} ==Others/non-official flags== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;background-color:#fff;border: 1px #6082B6 solid;" |- ! style="width:15%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Flag !! style="width:10%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Date !! style="width:30%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Use !! style="width:45%;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Description |- | [[File:1946 Canadian flag proposal.svg|100px|border]] || 1946 || Proposed Flag for Canada || A red British ensign defaced with a large golden maple leaf outlined in white in the fly. |- | [[File:Native Sons of Canada Flag.svg|100px|border]] || 1965 || Canadian flag proposal by the Native Sons of Canada || Party per bend Gules and Argent a maple leaf Gules |- | [[File:Canada Pearson Pennant 1964.svg|100px|border]] || 1965 || Proposed Flag for Canada, known as the ''Pearson Pennant'' || A blue field with a white square containing a three-leaf maple. The blue sides were meant to represent [[John A. Macdonald]]'s description of the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] and Canada's geography, "From sea to sea". |- | [[File:Canadian Duality Flag.svg|100px|border]] || 1994 || Proposed flag for Canada, known as the ''[[Canadian Unity Flag]]'' || Blue vertical stripes replacing part of the red bands, in approximate proportion to population of French heritage. |} ==University flags== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;background-color:#fff;border: 1px #6082B6 solid;" |- ! revision.text:
'''Magic Quadrant''' (MQ) refers to a series published by [[Information technology consulting|IT consulting firm]] [[Gartner]] of [[market research]] reports that rely on proprietary [[Qualitative research|qualitative]] [[data analysis]] methods to demonstrate market trends, such as direction, maturity and participants.<ref name="How Gartner Evaluates"> {{cite web | title=Magic Quadrants and MarketScopes: How Gartner Evaluates Vendors Within a Market | url=http://www.gartner.com/DisplayDocument?doc_cd=131166 | publisher=Gartner.com | date=February 2008 | accessdate=2009-07-27}}</ref> Their analyses are conducted for several specific technology industries and are updated every 1–2 years.
==Rating== Gartner rates vendors upon two criteria: ''completeness of [[vision statement|vision]]''<ref name="How Gartner Evaluates" /> and ''ability to execute''.<ref name="How Gartner Evaluates" /> Using a methodology which Gartner does not disclose{{Verification needed|date=May 2018}}, these component scores lead to a vendor position in one of four quadrants: *Leaders - Vendors in the Leaders quadrant have the highest composite scores for their Completeness of Vision and Ability to Execute. A vendor in the Leaders quadrant has the market share, credibility, and marketing & sales capabilities needed to drive the acceptance of new technologies. These vendors demonstrate a clear understanding of market needs, they are innovators and thought leaders, and they have well-articulated plans that customers and prospects can use when designing their infrastructures and strategies. In addition, they have a presence in the five major geographical regions, consistent financial performance, and broad platform support. *Challengers - A vendor in the Challengers quadrant participates in the market and executes well enough to be a serious threat to vendors in the Leaders quadrant. They have strong products, as well as sufficiently credible market position and resources to sustain continued growth. Financial viability is not an issue for vendors in the Challengers quadrant, but they lack the size and influence of vendors in the Leaders quadrant. *Visionaries - A vendor in the Visionaries quadrant delivers innovative products that address operationally or financially important end-user problems at a broad scale, but has not yet demonstrated the ability to capture market share or sustainable profitability. Visionary vendors are frequently privately held companies and acquisition targets for larger, established companies. The likelihood of acquisition often reduces the risks associated with installing their systems. *Niche Players - Vendors in the Niche Players quadrant are often narrowly focused on specific market or vertical segments. This quadrant may also include vendors that are adapting their existing products to enter the market under consideration, or larger vendors having difficulty developing and executing on their vision.
==Criticism== It has been pointed out that the criteria for the Magic Quadrant cater more towards [[investor]]s and large vendors than towards buyers.<ref>{{cite web | title=Looking beyond the magic quadrant to find the nitty-gritty | url=http://www.cmswatch.com/Trends/1660-Assessing-WCM-vendors | publisher=[[Real Story Group]] | date=2009-08-07 | accessdate=2009-08-08}}</ref>
Much of the criticism is focused on the lack of disclosure of the money received from the vendors it rates, raising [[conflict of interest]] issues. Also a source of criticism is the lack of disclosure on the vendor's component scores and the lack of transparency in Gartner's methodology used to derive the vendor's position on the MQ map.
The Magic Quadrant, and analysts in general, also skew the market: according to research conducted by a Scottish lecturer,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://analystrelations.org/2012/09/26/guest-post-why-it-vendors-should-take-industry-analysts-more-seriously |title=Why IT Vendors Should Take Industry Analysts (More) Seriously | Institute of Industry Analyst Relations |publisher=Analystrelations.org |date=2012-09-26 |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> by applying their methodologies to describe a market, they change that marketplace to fit their tools.
Another criticism is that open source vendors are not considered sufficiently by analysts like Gartner, as has been published in an online discussion between a VP from Talend and a German Research VP from Gartner.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vendor complains in a very public blog post about Gartner's Data Integration Magic Quadrant|url=http://sagecircle.wordpress.com/2008/12/29/vendor-complains-in-a-very-public-blog-post-about-gartners-data-integration-magic-quadrant/|publisher=Sagecircle.wordpress.com|date=2009-12-29|accessdate=2009-08-08}}</ref>
Gartner was the target of a [[federal law]]suit (filed May 29, 2009) from software vendor, [[ZL Technologies]], challenging the “legitimacy” of Gartner’s Magic Quadrant rating system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://analystrelations.org/2009/10/21/is-shooting-on-the-referee-productive/ |title=Is shooting on the referee productive? | Institute of Industry Analyst Relations |publisher=Analystrelations.org |date=2009-10-21 |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> Gartner filed a motion to dismiss by claiming [[First Amendment]] protection since it contends that its MQ reports contain "pure opinion," which legally means opinions which are not based on fact.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/21393241/ZL-v-Gartner-Complaint |title=ZL v Gartner Complaint |publisher=Scribd.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> The court threw out the ZL case because it lacked a specific complaint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprisestorageforum.com/continuity/features/article.php/3848461 |title=E-mail Archiving Vendor Takes on Gartner's Magic Quadrant |publisher=EnterpriseStorageForum.com |date=2009-11-13 |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref> That decision was upheld on appeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/memoranda/view.php?pk_id=0000007656 |title=Unpublished Dispositions (Memoranda) |publisher=Ca9.uscourts.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-02-24}}</ref>
==Analyzed markets== Analyzed markets include:<ref>{{cite web | title=Magic Quadrants and MarketScopes | url=http://www.gartner.com/it/products/mq/mq_ms.jsp | publisher=Gartner.com | date=2009-08-03 | accessdate=2009-08-08}}</ref> <!-- selection of representative items, preferably ones where citation is publicly available --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! revision.text:
{{for|the Japanese lexical law|Ōno's lexical law}}
'''Ohno's law''' was proposed by a Japanese-American biologist [[Susumu Ohno]], saying that the [[gene]] content of the [[mammal]]ian [[species]] has been conserved over species not only in the [[DNA]] content but also in the genes themselves. That is, nearly all mammalian species have conserved the [[X chromosome]] from their primordial X chromosome of a common ancestor.<ref name=Ohno67>Ohno S (1967). ''Sex Chromosomes and sex-linked genes.'' Berlin:Springer-Verlag.</ref>
== Evidence == As a [[Cell biology|cytological]] evidence, in first, mammalian X chromosomes in various species, including [[human]] and [[mouse]], have nearly the same size, with the content of about 5% of the genome. Second, for individual [[Locus (genetics)|gene loci]], a number of X-linked genes are common through mammalian species. Examples are found in [[glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase]] (G6PD), a gene for polypeptide of [[antihemophilic globulin]] (AHG or [[Factor VIII]]) in [[Haemophilia A|hemophilia A]] and [[Haemophilia B|B]], and plasma thromboplastin component gene (PTC or [[Factor IX]]). Moreover, no instances were found where an [[Sex linkage|X-linked]] gene in one species was located on an [[autosome]] in the other species.<ref name=Ohno67 />
== Conservation mechanisms == The content of a chromosome would be changed mainly by mutation after duplication of the chromosome and translocation with other chromosomes. However, in mammals, since the chromosomal [[Sex-determination system|sex-determination]] mechanism would have been established in their earlier stages of [[evolution]], [[polyploidy]] would have not occurred due to its incompatibility with the sex-determining mechanism. Moreover, X-autosome [[Chromosomal translocation|translocation]] would have been prohibited because it might have resulted in detrimental effects for survival to the organism. Thus in mammals, the content of X chromosomes has been conserved after typical 2 round duplication events at early ancestral stages of evolution, at the fish or amphibia ([[2R hypothesis]]).<ref name=Ohno67 /><ref name=Ohno70>Ohno S (1970). ''Evolution by Gene Duplication.'' London: Allen and Unwin, {{ISBN|0-04-575015-7}}.</ref>
== Contradicting and supportive evidence == Genes on the long arm of the human X are contained in the monotreme X and genes on the short arm of the human X are distributed on the autosomes of marsupials.<ref name=Watson>Watson JM, Riggs A, Graves JA (1992). "Gene mapping studies confirm the homology between the platypus X and echidna X1 chromosomes and identify a conserved ancestral monotreme X chromosome". ''Chromosoma'' 101(10): 596–601, {{PMID|1424984}}.</ref> Ohno commented to the result that [[monotreme]]s and [[marsupial]]s were not considered to be ancestors of true mammals, but they have diverged very early from the main line of mammals.<ref name=Ohno93>Ohno S (1993). "Patterns in genome evolution". ''Curr Opin Genet Dev'' 3(6): 911–914, {{PMID|8118217}}.</ref> [[Chloride channel]] gene (''CLCN4'') was mapped to the human X but on chromosome 7 of C57BL/6 mice, species of [[House Mouse|''Mus musculus'']], though the gene is located on X of [[Algerian Mouse|''Mus spretus'']] and [[rat]].<ref name=Palmer>Palmer S, Perry J, Ashworth A (1995). "A contravention of ohno's law in mice". ''Nat Genet'' 10(4): 472–476, {{PMID|7670497}}, {{DOI|10.1038/ng0895-472}}.</ref>
== Dictionaries having an article's name of ‘Ohno ‘s law’ == * Rédei GP (2003). "Ohno's law." ''Encyclopedic dictionary of genetics, genomics, and proteomics, 2nd ed.'' New York: Wiley-Liss, p. 870. {{ISBN|0-471-26821-6}}.
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:History of biology]] [[Category:Biology theories]] [[Category:Genetics]] [[Category:Evolutionary biology]]

{{redirect|On the Sizes and Distances|the work by Hipparchus|On Sizes and Distances}} {{italic title}} {{primary sources|date=November 2008}} [[Image:Aristarchus working.jpg|thumb|right|[[Aristarchus of Samos|Aristarchus's]] 3rd century BCE calculations on the relative sizes of, from left, the Sun, Earth and Moon, from a 10th-century CE Greek copy]] '''''On the Sizes and Distances (of the Sun and Moon)''''' (Περὶ μεγεθῶν καὶ ἀποστημάτων [ἡλίου καὶ σελήνης], ''Peri megethon kai apostematon'') is widely accepted as the only extant work written by [[Aristarchus of Samos]], an ancient Greek astronomer who lived circa 310–230 BCE. This work calculates the sizes of the [[Sun]] and [[Moon]], as well as their distances from the [[Earth]] in terms of Earth's radius.
The book was presumably preserved by students of [[Pappus of Alexandria]]'s course in mathematics, although there is no evidence of this. The ''[[editio princeps]]'' was published by [[John Wallis]] in 1688, using several medieval manuscripts compiled by Sir [[Henry Savile (Bible translator)|Henry Savile]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Heath|first1=Thomas|title=Aristarchus of Samos, the Ancient Copernicus|date=1913|authorlink=Thomas Little Heath|url=https://archive.org/details/aristarchusofsam00heat|publisher=Clarendon|location=Oxford|page=[https://archive.org/stream/aristarchusofsam00heat#page/323/mode/1up 323]}}</ref> The earliest Latin translation was made by [[Giorgio Valla]] in 1488. There is also a [https://www.loc.gov/resource/rbctos.2017gen18687 1572 Latin translation and commentary] by [[Frederico Commandino]].<ref>Berggren and Sidoli. 2007. 'Aristarchus's On the Sizes and Distances of the Sun and the Moon: Greek and Arabic Texts'. Arch. Hist. Exact Sci. 61(3), pp. 213–54. DOI: 10.1007/s00407-006-0118-4</ref><ref>Noack B. (1992) Aristarch von Samos: Untersuchungen zur Überlieferungsgeschichte der Schrif ''Περὶ μεγεθῶν καὶ ἀποστημάτων ἡλίου καὶ σελήνης'', Wiesbaden.</ref>
==Symbols== The work's method relied on several observations: * The apparent size of the Sun and the Moon in the sky. * The size of the Earth's shadow in relation to the Moon during a [[lunar eclipse]] * The angle between the Sun and Moon during a [[Lunar phase|half moon]] is very close to 90°.
The rest of the article details a reconstruction of Aristarchus' method and results.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LXHxx8L9YFo A video on reconstruction of Aristarchus' method]</ref> The reconstruction uses the following variables: {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Symbol!!Meaning |- |align = "center"|''φ''||Angle between the Moon and the Sun during a half moon (directly measurable) |- |align = "center"|''L''||Distance from the Earth to the [[Moon]] |- |align = "center"|''S''||Distance from the Earth to the [[Sun]] |- |align = "center"|''ℓ''||Radius of the [[Moon]] |- |align = "center"|''s''||Radius of the [[Sun]] |- |align = "center"|''t''||Radius of the [[Earth]] |- |align = "center"|''D''||Distance from the center of Earth to the vertex of Earth's shadow cone |- |align = "center"|''d''||Radius of the Earth's shadow at the location of the Moon |- |align = "center"|''n''||Ratio, ''d/ℓ'' (a directly observable quantity during a [[lunar eclipse]]) |- |align = "center"|''x''||Ratio, ''S/L'' = ''s/ℓ'' (which is calculated from ''φ'') |}
==Half Moon== Aristarchus began with the premise that, during a [[Lunar phase|half moon]], the moon forms a [[right triangle]] with the Sun and Earth. By observing the angle between the Sun and Moon, ''φ'', the ratio of the distances to the Sun and Moon could be deduced using a form of [[trigonometry]].
[[Image:AristarchusHalfLitMoon2.png]]
From the diagram and trigonometry, we can calculate that
: <math> \frac{S}{L} = \frac{1}{\cos \varphi} = \sec \varphi. </math>
The diagram is greatly exaggerated, because in reality, ''S = 390 L'', and ''φ'' is extremely close to 90°. Aristarchus determined ''φ'' to be a thirtieth of a quadrant (in modern terms, 3°) less than a right angle: in current terminology, 87°. Trigonometric functions had not yet been invented, but using geometrical analysis in the style of [[Euclid]], Aristarchus determined that
: <math>18 < \frac{S}{L} < 20.</math>
In other words, the distance to the Sun was somewhere between 18 and 20 times greater than the distance to the Moon. This value (or values close to it) was accepted by astronomers for the next two thousand years, until the invention of the telescope permitted a more precise estimate of [[solar parallax]].
Aristarchus also reasoned that as the [[angular size]] of the Sun and the Moon were the same, but the distance to the Sun was between 18 and 20 times further than the Moon, the Sun must therefore be 18-20 times larger.
==Lunar eclipse== Aristarchus then used another construction based on a lunar eclipse:
[[Image:AristarchusLunar Eclipse2.png]]
By similarity of the triangles, <math> \frac{D}{L} = \frac{t}{t-d} \quad </math> and <math>\quad \frac{D}{S} = \frac{t}{s-t}.</math>
Dividing these two equations and using the observation that the apparent sizes of the Sun and Moon are the same, <math>\frac{L}{S} = \frac{\ell}{s}</math>, yields
: <math> \frac{\ell}{s} = \frac{t-d}{s-t} \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \frac{s-t}{s} = \frac{t-d}{\ell} \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ 1 - \frac{t}{s} = \frac{t}{\ell} - \frac{d}{\ell} \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \frac{t}{\ell} + \frac{t}{s} = 1 + \frac{d}{\ell}.</math>
The rightmost equation can either be solved for ''ℓ/t''
:<math> \frac{t}{\ell}(1+\frac{\ell}{s}) = 1 + \frac{d}{\ell} \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \frac{\ell}{t} = \frac{1+\frac{\ell}{s}}{1 + \frac{d}{\ell}}.</math>
or ''s/t''
:<math> \frac{t}{s}(1+\frac{s}{\ell}) = 1 + \frac{d}{\ell} \ \ \Rightarrow \ \ \frac{s}{t} = \frac{1+\frac{s}{\ell}}{1 + \frac{d}{\ell}}.</math>
The appearance of these equations can be simplified using ''n'' = ''d/ℓ'' and ''x'' = ''s/ℓ''.
: <math> \frac{\ell}{t} = \frac{1+x}{x(1+n)}</math>
: <math> \frac{s}{t} = \frac{1+x}{1+n}</math>
The above equations give the radii of the Moon and Sun entirely in terms of observable quantities.
The following formulae give the distances to the Sun and Moon in terrestrial units:
: <math> \frac{L}{t} = \left( \frac{\ell}{t} \right) \left( \frac{180}{\pi \theta} \right) </math>
: <math> \frac{S}{t} = \left( \frac{s}{t} \right) \left( \frac{180}{\pi \theta} \right) </math>
where ''θ'' is the apparent radius of the Moon and Sun measured in degrees.
It is unlikely that Aristarchus used these exact formulae, yet these formulae are likely a good approximation to those of Aristarchus.
==Results== The above formulae can be used to reconstruct the results of Aristarchus. The following table shows the results of a long-standing (but dubious) reconstruction using ''n'' = 2, ''x'' = 19.1 (''φ'' = 87°) and ''θ'' = 1°, alongside the modern day accepted values.
{| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Qu|Quantity||Relation||Reconstruction||Modern |-align = "center" |''s/t''||Sun's radius in Earth radii||6.7||109 |-align = "center" |''t/ℓ''||Earth's radius in Moon radii||2.85||3.50 |-align = "center" |''L/t''||Earth-Moon distance in Earth radii||20||60.32 |-align = "center" |''S/t''||Earth-Sun distance in Earth radii||380||23,500 |}{{citation needed|reason = needs credible references for modern values|date=February 2016}}
The error in this calculation comes primarily from the poor values for ''x'' and ''θ''. The poor value for ''θ'' is especially surprising, since [[Archimedes]] writes that Aristarchus was the first to determine that the Sun and Moon had an apparent diameter of half a degree. This would give a value of ''θ'' = 0.25, and a corresponding distance to the moon of 80 Earth radii, a much better estimate. The disagreement of the work with Archimedes seems to be due to its taking an Aristarchus statement that the lunisolar diameter is 1/15 of a "meros" of the zodiac to mean 1/15 of a zodiacal sign (30°), unaware that the Greek word "meros" meant either "portion" or 7°1/2; and 1/15 of the latter amount is 1°/2, in agreement with Archimedes' testimony.
A [[Hipparchus On Sizes and Distances|similar procedure]] was later used by [[Hipparchus]], who estimated the mean distance to the moon as 67 Earth radii, and [[Ptolemy]], who took 59 Earth radii for this value.
==Illustrations== Some interactive illustrations of the propositions in ''On Sizes'' can be found here: * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/ZYFQqZa5 '''Hypothesis 4'''] states that when the moon appears to us halved, its distance from the sun is then less than a quadrant by one-thirtieth of a quadrant [that is, it is less than 90° by 1/30th of 90° or 3°, and is therefore equal to 87°] (Heath 1913:353). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/BcVB8g23 '''Proposition 1'''] states that two equal spheres are comprehended by one and the same cylinder, and two unequal spheres by one and the same cone which has its vertex in the direction of the lesser sphere; and the straight line drawn through the centres of the spheres is at right angles to each of the circles in which the surface of the cylinder, or of the cone, touches the spheres (Heath 1913:354). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/EsGKE5yA '''Proposition 2'''] states that if a sphere be illuminated by a sphere greater than itself, the illuminated portion of the former sphere will be greater than a hemisphere (Heath 1913:358). * [http://www.geogebratube.org/student/m1506 '''Proposition 3'''] states that the circle in the moon which divides the dark and the bright portions is least when the cone comprehending both the sun and the moon has its vertex at our eye (Heath 1913:362). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/dxJPXypp '''Proposition 4'''] states that the circle which divides the dark and the bright portions in the moon is not perceptibly different from a great circle in the moon (Heath 1913:365). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/MYdPsEku '''Proposition 6'''] states that the moon moves [in an orbit] lower than [that of] the sun, and, when it is halved, is distant less than a quadrant from the sun (Heath 1913:372). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/u4EKJ5uQ '''Proposition 7'''] states that the distance of the sun from the earth is greater than 18 times, but less than 20 times, the distance of the moon from the earth (Heath 1913:377). In other words, the sun is 18 to 20 times farther away and wider than the moon. * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/rDNQhNx9 '''Proposition 13'''] states that the straight line subtending the portion intercepted within the earth's shadow of the circumference of the circle in which the extremities of the diameter of the circle dividing the dark and the bright portions in the moon move is less than double of the diameter of the moon, but has to it a ratio greater than that which 88 has to 45; and it is less than 1/9th part of the diameter of the sun, but has to it a ratio greater than that which 21 has to 225. But it has to the straight line drawn from the centre of the sun at right angles to the axis and meeting the sides of the cone a ratio greater than that which 979 has to 10 125 (Heath 1913:394). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/nCqsrFSQ '''Proposition 14'''] states that the straight line joined from the centre of the earth to the centre of the moon has to the straight line cut off from the axis towards the centre of the moon by the straight line subtending the [circumference] within the earth's shadow a ratio greater than that which 675 has to 1 (Heath 1913:400). * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/eChNpgEj '''Proposition 15'''] states that the diameter of the sun has to the diameter of the earth a ratio greater than 19/3, but less than 43/6 (Heath 1913:403). This means that the sun is (a mean of) 6¾ times wider than the earth, or that the sun is 13½ earth-radii wide. The moon and sun must then be 20¼ and 387 earth-radii away from us in order to subtend an angular size of 2º. * [https://www.geogebra.org/m/GrQBA2pf '''Proposition 17a'''] in al-Tusi's medieval Arabic version of the book ''On Sizes'' states that the ratio of the distance of the vertex of the shadow cone from the center of the moon (when the moon is on the axis [that is, at the middle of an eclipse] of the cone containing the earth and the sun) to the distance of the center of the moon from the center of the earth is greater than the ratio 71 to 37 and less than the ratio 3 to one (Berggren & Sidoli 2007:218).<ref name=Berggren>Berggren, J. L. & N. Sidoli (2007) {{cite web |url=http://individual.utoronto.ca/acephalous/Berggren_Sidoli_2007a.pdf |title=‘Aristarchus's On the Sizes and Distances of the Sun and the Moon: Greek and Arabic Texts’, ''Archive for History of Exact Sciences,'' Vol. 61, no. 3, 213-254 |accessdate=2011-11-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428064826/http://individual.utoronto.ca/acephalous/Berggren_Sidoli_2007a.pdf |archivedate=April 28, 2011 |df= }}.</ref> In other words, that the tip of the earth’s shadow cone is between 108/37 and 4 times farther away than the moon.
==Known copies== * Library of Congress Vatican Exhibit.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last1=Heath|first1=Thomas|title=Aristarchus of Samos, the Ancient Copernicus|date=1913|authorlink=Thomas Little Heath|url=https://archive.org/details/aristarchusofsam00heat|publisher=Clarendon|location=Oxford}} This was later reprinted, see ({{ISBN|0-486-43886-4}}). * van Helden, A. ''Measuring the Universe: Cosmic Dimensions from Aristarchus to Halley''. Chicago: Univ. of Chicago Pr., 1985. {{ISBN|0-226-84882-5}}.

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic_links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:PermaLink/772743896#Future_of_magic_links|local RfC]] - [[User:PrimeBOT/13|BRFA]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use British English|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Peter Dollond |image = John Hoppner 001.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |birth_date = 24 February 1731{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} |birth_place = [[Kensington]], [[England]] |death_date = {{d-da|2 July 1820|24 February 1731}}{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = [[Optics]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Achromatic lens]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Peter Dollond''' (24 February 1731{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} – 2 July 1820{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} born [[Kensington]]{{citation needed|date=December 2014}}, [[England]]) was an English maker of [[optical instruments]], the son of [[John Dollond]]. He is known for his successful optics business, and for the invention of the [[apochromat]].
==Biography== Working together with his father and subsequently with his younger brother and nephew ([[George Dollond]]) he successfully designed and manufactured a number of optical instruments. He is particularly credited with the invention of the triple [[achromatic lens]] - i.e., [[apochromatic lens]] - in 1763, still in wide use today,<ref>Ronald Pearsall, ''Collecting and Restoring Scientific Instruments'', David and Charles, London 1974, {{ISBN|0-7153-6354-9}}</ref><ref name=Stargazer>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2LZZginzib4C&pg=PA140 |title=Stargazer: the life and times of the telescope |first=Fred |last=Watson |publisher=Allen & Unwin |date=2007 |pages=140–55 |isbn=978-1-74175-383-7}}</ref> though known as the [[Cooke triplet]] after a much later 1893 patent.
Peter Dollond worked at first silk weaving with his father, but his father's passion for optics inspired him so much that in 1750 Peter quit the silk business and opened an optical instruments shop in [[Kennington]], [[London]]. After two years, his father gave up silk, too, and joined him.
Dollond telescopes, for [[star|sidereal]] or terrestrial use, were amongst the most popular in both Great Britain and abroad for a period of over one and half centuries. Admiral [[Lord Nelson]] himself owned one. Another had sailed with [[James Cook|Captain Cook]] in 1769 to observe the [[Transit of Venus]].
The Peter Dollond compound chest [[microscope]] is based on improvements to the Cuff-style microscope introduced by British scientific instrument designers [[Edward Nairne]] and Thomas Blunt around 1780. Another design was for the Peter Dollond compound monocular Eriometer around 1790 used to accurately measure the thickness and size of [[wool]] fibres.
After successfully defending a legal challenge to the patent he held for the achromatic lens the business prospered and he successfully sued his rivals for patent infringement.<ref name=Stargazer/> Dollond's reputation, especially with his father being a Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] as a result of his development and patenting of the [[achromatic lens|achromat]], provided the company with the [[de facto]] [[Right of first refusal|right of refusal]] on the best optical [[flint glass]].<ref name="daumas">Daumas, Maurice, ''Scientific Instruments of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries and Their Makers'', Portman Books, London 1989 {{ISBN|978-0-7134-0727-3}}</ref> This privilege permitted Dollond to maintain an edge in quality over competitor's telescopes and optical instruments for many years.
Notable customers also included:<ref name=Stargazer/>
*[[Leopold Mozart]] *[[Frederick the Great]] *[[Thomas Jefferson]]
Dollond & Co merged with Aitchison & Co in 1927 to form [[Dollond & Aitchison]], the well-known British high street chain of [[optician]]s.
Peter Dollond's wife was Ann Phillips and they had two daughters, Louise and Anne.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers |last=Hockey |first=Thomas |date=2009 |publisher=[[Springer Publishing]] |isbn=978-0-387-31022-0 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |url=http://www.springerreference.com/docs/html/chapterdbid/58374.html}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{commonscat-inline}}
{{Authority control}}
